lines.text: Única
lines.translation: Unique
lines.grammar: The adjective "única" is used to describe a singular or one-of-a-kind entity, emphasizing its uniqueness.

lines.text: Tu boca besándome toda de una forma única
lines.translation: Your mouth kissing me all over in a unique way
lines.grammar: The phrase "toda de una forma" is an idiomatic expression that conveys the idea of something being done thoroughly or completely, with "una forma" implying uniqueness.

lines.text: Tanta gente en el mundo y esa noche yo era la única
lines.translation: So many people in the world, and that night I was the only one.
lines.grammar: The phrase "yo era" is a past perfect construction, indicating that at some point before that specific night, the speaker had been the only one. The use of "era" instead of "fui" emphasizes the duration of this state rather than its completion.

lines.text: Lo entregamos todo sabiendo que iba a ser la única
lines.translation: We gave it our all knowing it was going to be the only one
lines.grammar: The phrase "sabiendo que" is an idiomatic expression indicating a hypothetical or assumed situation, equivalent to "knowing that" in English.

lines.text: Y han pasado mil noches, eh-eh
lines.translation: And a thousand nights have passed, eh-eh
lines.grammar: The use of "han" in "Y han pasado mil noches" is an example of the present perfect tense, indicating that the action of passing nights started in the past and continues up to the moment of speaking.

lines.text: Y sigues tan presente, eh-eh
lines.translation: And you're still so present, eh-eh
lines.grammar: The use of "sigues" (you continue) in the present perfect tense indicates that the speaker's presence is ongoing or continuous. The "eh-eh" interjection adds a playful and informal tone to the sentence.

lines.text: El olor del momento, bebé
lines.translation: The smell of the moment, baby
lines.grammar: This phrase uses the present participle "del momento" to describe a fleeting or ephemeral experience, emphasizing the idea that the moment is being savored in real-time. The use of "bebé" as an affectionate term adds a playful tone to the phrase.

lines.text: Se ha quedado pa siempre, eh-eh
lines.translation: It's here to stay, eh-eh
lines.grammar: The phrase "se ha quedado" is in the present perfect tense, indicating that something has a lasting effect. The use of "pa siempre" is an idiomatic expression meaning "forever" or "always".

lines.text: Y aunque estemos distantes, eh-eh
lines.translation: And even though we're far apart, eh-eh
lines.grammar: The use of "estamos" (we are) in the present tense indicates that the speaker is expressing a general truth or a habitual situation, rather than describing a specific moment. The "eh-eh" interjection adds a playful and informal tone to the sentence.

lines.text: Sé que tú también sientes, eh-eh
lines.translation: I know you feel it too, eh-eh
lines.grammar: The use of "sientes" (you feel) in the present tense indicates that the speaker is expressing a general truth or shared experience, rather than describing a specific moment. The phrase "tú también" emphasizes the inclusive nature of this feeling.

lines.text: Y cuando ames a alguien, bebé
lines.translation: And when you love someone, baby
lines.grammar: This line uses the present tense to express a general truth about loving someone, and the idiomatic expression "bebé" is an affectionate term used to emphasize the sentiment.

lines.text: Sé que vas a extrañarme, eh-eh
lines.translation: I know you're going to miss me, eh-eh
lines.grammar: The use of "vas" instead of "vayas" is an informal, colloquial way to express the future tense in Spanish, common in spoken language and song lyrics.

lines.text: Porque yo te pienso si me besan
lines.translation: Because I think of you when I get kissed.
lines.grammar: In this line, the verb "pienso" is in the present tense and imperfect aspect, indicating a habitual or continuous action. The phrase "yo te pienso" can be translated as "I think of you" and implies a strong emotional connection between the speaker and the person being addressed.

lines.text: Bebé, tu recuerdo no me deja
lines.translation: Baby, your memory won't leave me.
lines.grammar: The phrase "no me deja" is an idiomatic expression meaning "won't leave" or "can't forget", using the present tense to convey a sense of ongoing emotional impact.

lines.text: To lo que hicimos se ha quedado
lines.translation: Everything we did has stayed
lines.grammar: The verb "ha quedado" is in the present perfect tense, indicating that the action of what they did has a connection to the present moment. The phrase "se ha quedado" can be translated as "has stayed" and implies a sense of permanence or lasting impact.

lines.text: Como un tattoo en mi cabeza
lines.translation: Like a tattoo on my head
lines.grammar: This idiomatic expression uses the verb "ser" in the present tense to convey a permanent or lasting quality, similar to English phrases like "it's written all over my face.

lines.text: Nada puede salir mal, tú y yo en el mismo canal
lines.translation: Nothing can go wrong, you and I are on the same page
lines.grammar: The phrase "tú y yo" is an idiomatic expression meaning "you and me" in English, emphasizing the speaker's close relationship with the listener.

lines.text: Sonó el teléfono, él me dijo: "No vayas a contestar
lines.translation: The phone rang, he told me: "Don't answer it
lines.grammar: In this context, the verb "sonó" is in the preterite tense, indicating that the phone ringing occurred before the main action of the sentence. The use of the pronoun "él" agrees with the subject "él" mentioned earlier, emphasizing the speaker's instructions.

lines.text: Quédate conmigo, ma"
